markdown:
# School of Health and Life Sciences | Glasgow Caledonian University

Welcome to the School of Health and Life Sciences at GCU. The school is committed to the pursuit of excellence in teaching, research and knowledge transfer across the disciplines of allied health, nursing and social work, biological and biomedical sciences, psychology and vision sciences.

![Returning to nursing at Glasgow Caledonian University](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0004/10300/varieties/large.jpg)

## About us

Our school is full of exciting and career focused courses. Learn more about our departments, facilities and roles within the school.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/aboutus)

The school is one of three Glasgow-based academic schools at GCU and brings together eight departments: Biological and Biomedical Sciences; Nursing and Community Health; Occupational Therapy and Human Nutrition and Dietetics; Physiotherapy and Paramedicine; Podiatry and Radiography; Psychology; Social Work and Vision Sciences.

Working in partnership with staff, students and external stakeholders, the School of Health and Life Sciences has created a unifying vision designed to meet the 2030 University Strategy, embedding excellence, engagement and energy into every aspect of school life.

### Research

![MSc Physiotherapy classroom equipment in Glasgow Caledonian University](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0003/10011/varieties/medium.jpg)

#### Postgraduate research study

We welcome applications from PhD research students and offer a range of flexible PhD Studentships to fund today’s biggest global challenges.

#### Research Centre for Health (ReaCH)

The centre aims to make a direct and significant contribution to Sustainable Development Goal 3: Good Health and Well-Being.

#### Research groups

Find programmes of research which are taking place across the School of Health and Life Sciences.

[Discover more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/research)

## Practice Based Learning

Practice Based Learning (PrBL) is integral to the learning and professional development in all our health and social care pre-registration programmes. Students on these programmes spend approximately 30% to 50% of the overall programme of study on practice placements.

![Student diagnostic radiographers produce and interpret images at Glasgow Caledonian University](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0027/9990/varieties/large.jpg)

## Practice Based Learning (PrBL)

PrBL is integral to the learning and professional development of our health and social care pre-registration programmes.

## Professional regulation

Not only are practice placements ideal environments for experiential learning and consolidating theory, but the hours students complete in PrBL situations are required for professional regulation within the UK. Successful completion of pre-registration awards in the subject areas of biomedical science, counselling psychology, diagnostic imaging, dietetics, nursing, occupational therapy, oral health science, orthoptics, paramedic science, physiotherapy, podiatry, radiotherapy and oncology, lead to graduate eligibility to register with one of the following regulatory bodies: General Dental Council (GDC); Health and Care Professions Council (HCPC); Nursing Midwifery Council (NMC); and the Scottish Social Services Council (SSSC).

![](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0022/4936/varieties/large.jpg)

## Contact the school

Our management and support team will be happy to assist with any questions.

[Contact us](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/contactus)

## Practice environment

Our practice-based learning approaches have been developed to reflect the aims of each programme of study and to ensure that opportunities exist for students to develop and apply theoretical knowledge, consolidate and extend practical skills, refine problem solving and clinical reasoning abilities, and advance a reflective approach to professional practice. PrBL is designed to prepare students for future practice by equipping them with the skills and knowledge to respond to the demands of the ever-changing practice environment. Placements are carefully planned to provide each student with experience in the core areas of practice in a range of different practice settings, thus encouraging them to develop a keen sense of their role within their own respective profession.

## Explore the school

Postgraduate

The School of Health and Life Sciences is committed to the pursuit of excellence in the disciplines of health, nursing and social care, biological and biomedical sciences, psychology and vision sciences.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/study/postgraduate)

Undergraduate

Study one of our undergraduate courses at GCU's School of Health and Life Sciences.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/study/undergraduate)

International students

We have international students from over 100 different countries studying in the School of Health and Life Sciences. Find out about our courses.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/study/international)

Part-time and flexible

Balancing study with work is challenging, and with this in mind, we offer a range of day release, evening, revision and online and flexible learning degrees.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls/study/part-timeandflexible)

markdown:
# Common Good | Glasgow Caledonian University

Our ambitious **vision** is that, by 2030, Glasgow Caledonian University will be recognised as a world-leading University for social innovation. The **Sustainable Development Goals**, a universal call to action to end poverty, protect the planet and ensure that all people enjoy peace and prosperity, provide the guiding framework for delivery of our Strategy 2030.

Caledonian Club

The Caledonian Club is Glasgow Caledonian University’s multi-award winning widening participation and community engagement initiative, working across our local communities in Glasgow, London and New York.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/caledonianclub)

Common Good Award

The Common Good Award is a skills and personal development award which aims to encourage, support and reward students who are engaged in co and extra-curricular activity aligned to the Common Good.

[Learn more](https://spark.adobe.com/page/EhrGZ5hUxL3J8/)

Common Good First

A global network to connect community projects to each other - and to universities around the world

[Learn more](https://www.commongoodfirst.com/)

Common Good Curriculum

You can find Information on The Common Good Attributes and what we mean by each one.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/commongoodcurriculum)

Community and public engagement

The community and public engagement team are your first point of contact with the University. We are here to provide you with access to research and teaching initiatives that can benefit your community.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/communityandpublicengagement)

GCU economic impact

Find out about the difference we make in the local and global community.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/economicimpact)

Equality and diversity

Information on GCU's inclusive and supportive learning and working environment. 

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/equality)

Erase the Grey

The Erase the Grey campaign - launched by GCU -  has key messages which challenge stereotypical attitudes and behaviours and reiterates a zero-tolerance policy towards gender-based violence.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/erasethegrey)

GCU Foundation

Discover more about supporting GCU students and our vital projects through the work of our Foundation.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/foundation)

Social innovation

Social innovation involves new strategies, ideas and organisations that meet social needs of all kinds. It flourishes when people from different backgrounds and experiences come together to produce new ideas and initiatives.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/socialinnovation)

Sustainable Development Goals

A collection of 17 global goals were introduced by the United Nations as a set of targets through which the world can tackle the biggest economic, social and environmental challenges we currently face.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/sustainabledevelopmentgoals)

Sustainability

Glasgow Caledonian University is committed to carbon neutrality by 2040 and as the University for the Common Good, the principles of sustainable development are incorporated into every aspect of our operations.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/sustainability)

metadata.title: School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment | Glasgow Caledonian University | Scotland, UK
metadata.description: GCU's School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of three academic schools with strong industry links supported by innovation in our teaching

openGraph.content: School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment
GCU's School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of three academic schools with strong industry links supported by innovation in our teaching

text:
School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment | Glasgow Caledonian University
We thrive on ideas, support innovation and value the importance of social responsibility and the Common Good. We deliver modern, innovative and exciting programmes. We also teach the largest number of part-time and work-based students in Scotland.
SCEBE Celebration
SCEBE graduates, students and academics from across the School were joined by key stakeholders to celebrate the success of our courses and partnerships.
Commited to gender equality
SCEBE has been formally recognised for its commitment to gender equality by attaining the Advance HE's Athena SWAN Institutional Silver Award.
Find out more 
Our subjects range from Computing Games, Civil Engineering, Construction Management, Cyber Security, Data Science and Artificial Intelligence, Digital Design to Forensic Investigation, Electrical Engineering, Environmental Management, Mechanical Engineering, Surveying and User Experience (UX).
Our facilities
You will find cutting-edge facilities and teaching informed by breakthrough research taking place here on campus. We have invested millions of pounds in our virtual reality and testing facilities including our emotion lab and 360 degree Igloo.
Industry partners
You will find lots of resources and support when seeking your graduate job from our careers service. Through research, industrial placement programmes and Graduate Apprentice programmes we have developed valuable partnerships for students.
Our expertise
With research strengths in sustainable environments, we explore this societal challenge across the Built Environment Asset Management research centre, the Centre for Climate Justice, and SMART Technology Centre.
The School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment offers flexible study options including hybrid learning, online learning, distance learning, and work-based learning to support a wide range of full-time and part-time students.
Research
Several Research Centres have been established as part of the drive to promote multi-disciplinary research across the School.
Learn more arrow_forward 
Undergraduate
Undergraduate programmes are designed in partnership with industry and colleges to help you transition from student to graduate to professional.
Learn more arrow_forward 
Part-time and flexible
We deliver flexible, multi-disciplinary, high quality education and training opportunities that meet the needs of individual professionals as well as organisations.
Learn more arrow_forward 
Postgraduate study
The School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of the leading schools for programmes in building and surveying in the UK, and carries out extensive research in partnership with industry, commerce and other institutions
Learn more arrow_forward 
Most of our programmes are accredited by professional bodies including the British Computer Society (BCS), the Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET), the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE), Institution of Civil Engineers (ICE), Institution of Structural Engineers the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS), the Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB) and the Institute of Measurement & Control (InstMC), JAMES and many more.
Follow us
Join in the conversation and follow us on our social channels
Follow us
markdown:
# School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment | Glasgow Caledonian University

We thrive on ideas, support innovation and value the importance of social responsibility and the Common Good. We deliver modern, innovative and exciting programmes. We also teach the largest number of part-time and work-based students in Scotland.

### SCEBE Celebration

SCEBE graduates, students and academics from across the School were joined by key stakeholders to celebrate the success of our courses and partnerships.

* * *

![Athena Swan logo with GCU graphics surrounding](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0012/128010/varieties/large.jpg)

## Commited to gender equality

SCEBE has been formally recognised for its commitment to gender equality by attaining the Advance HE's Athena SWAN Institutional Silver Award.

[Find out more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/commongood/equality/genderequality/athenaswanatgcu)

Our subjects range from Computing Games, Civil Engineering, Construction Management, Cyber Security, Data Science and Artificial Intelligence, Digital Design to Forensic Investigation, Electrical Engineering, Environmental Management, Mechanical Engineering, Surveying and User Experience (UX).

![Charlotte Henderson and Bobbi-Joe Ferguson, BSc (Hons) Applied Computer Games students, working in a filming studio on Glasgow campus. Photo taken in November 2021.](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0016/10258/varieties/medium.jpeg)

#### Our facilities

You will find cutting-edge facilities and teaching informed by breakthrough research taking place here on campus. We have invested millions of pounds in our virtual reality and testing facilities including our emotion lab and 360 degree Igloo.

#### Industry partners

You will find lots of resources and support when seeking your graduate job from our careers service. Through research, industrial placement programmes and Graduate Apprentice programmes we have developed valuable partnerships for students.

#### Our expertise

With research strengths in sustainable environments, we explore this societal challenge across the Built Environment Asset Management research centre, the Centre for Climate Justice, and SMART Technology Centre.

The School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment offers flexible study options including hybrid learning, online learning, distance learning, and work-based learning to support a wide range of full-time and part-time students.

Research

Several Research Centres have been established as part of the drive to promote multi-disciplinary research across the School.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/cebe/research)

Undergraduate

Undergraduate programmes are designed in partnership with industry and colleges to help you transition from student to graduate to professional.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/cebe/study/undergraduate)

Part-time and flexible

We deliver flexible, multi-disciplinary, high quality education and training opportunities that meet the needs of individual professionals as well as organisations.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/cebe/study/part-timeandflexible)

Postgraduate study

The School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of the leading schools for programmes in building and surveying in the UK, and carries out extensive research in partnership with industry, commerce and other institutions

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/cebe/study/postgraduate)

Most of our programmes are accredited by professional bodies including the [British Computer Society (BCS)](http://www.bcs.org/ "Chartered Institute for IT"), the [Institute of Engineering and Technology (IET)](http://www.theiet.org/ "Institution of Engineering and Technology"), the [Institution of Mechanical Engineers (IMechE)](http://www.imeche.org/ "IMechE"), Institution of Civil Engineers (ICE), [Institution of Structural Engineers](https://www.istructe.org/) the [Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors (RICS)](http://www.rics.org/uk "RICS"), the [Chartered Institute of Building (CIOB)](http://www.ciob.org/ "CIOB") and the Institute of Measurement & Control (InstMC), [JAMES](https://www.jamesonline.org.uk/) and many more.

![](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0023/4937/varieties/large.jpg)

## Follow us

Join in the conversation and follow us on our social channels

Follow us

metadata.description: Learn how the University is actioning its committment to a culture of positive physical and mental health of our students and staff.

openGraph.content: Learn how the University is actioning its committment to a culture of positive physical and mental health of our students and staff.

text:
Mental Health and Wellbeing | Glasgow Caledonian University
As the University of the Common Good, Glasgow Caledonian has set out a clear intention to make transformative changes in the health and wellbeing of our whole community, creating an environment that supports and promotes positive mental health, a healthy work-life balance and opportunities for professional development, personal effectiveness and progression.
We are committed to a culture of positive physical and mental health, allowing our students and staff to reach their full potential. We proactively support a positive environment to work and study, providing information, training, guidance and practical tips on how to support yourself and others around you.
Find the support you need
Student Wellbeing
We provides a free, confidential advice and support service in a safe and non-judgemental environment.
Get support arrow_forward 
Staff Wellbeing
Get practical guidance and advice to support postive wellbeing for yourself and others in the University.
Get support arrow_forward 
Our projects
Our vision is to proactively support the mental health and wellbeing of our people and promote a healthy learning and working environment.
We've taken a whole university approach to ensure the wellbeing of all our staff and students based on the Universities UK Step Change framework and through our strategic engagement with sector projects and partners. These include our ongoing partnership with the Scottish Action for Mental Health (SAMH), our work with the Student Minds’ University Mental Health Charter, and our Student Mental Health Agreements.
The University regularly hosts events and campaigns to raise awareness and tackle mental health issues in a supportive and authentic way, creating an open culture that encourages engagement with the available support.
markdown:
# Mental Health and Wellbeing | Glasgow Caledonian University

As the University of the Common Good, Glasgow Caledonian has set out a clear intention to make transformative changes in the health and wellbeing of our whole community, creating an environment that supports and promotes positive mental health, a healthy work-life balance and opportunities for professional development, personal effectiveness and progression.

We are committed to a culture of positive physical and mental health, allowing our students and staff to reach their full potential. We proactively support a positive environment to work and study, providing information, training, guidance and practical tips on how to support yourself and others around you.

## Find the support you need

Student Wellbeing

We provides a free, confidential advice and support service in a safe and non-judgemental environment.

[Get support arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/support/wellbeing)

Staff Wellbeing

Get practical guidance and advice to support postive wellbeing for yourself and others in the University.

[Get support arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/supportservices/peopleservices/wellbeing)

## Our projects

Our vision is to proactively support the mental health and wellbeing of our people and promote a healthy learning and working environment.

We've taken a whole university approach to ensure the wellbeing of all our staff and students based on the [Universities UK Step Change framework](https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/what-we-do/policy-and-research/publications/stepchange-mentally-healthy-universities "https://www.universitiesuk.ac.uk/what-we-do/policy-and-research/publications/stepchange-mentally-healthy-universities") and through our strategic engagement with sector projects and partners. These include our ongoing partnership with the Scottish Action for Mental Health (SAMH), our work with the Student Minds’ University Mental Health Charter, and our Student Mental Health Agreements.

The University regularly hosts events and campaigns to raise awareness and tackle mental health issues in a supportive and authentic way, creating an open culture that encourages engagement with the available support.

markdown:
# International partnerships | Glasgow Caledonian University

The development of long-term partnerships with overseas institutions is a fundamental part of Glasgow Caledonian University’s Strategy 2030. From articulation and pathway partnerships, and student and staff mobility, to overseas campus partnerships, the University is dedicated to increasing its global network.

The International Partnerships Office at Glasgow Caledonian University comprises the International Partnership Team and the Exchange and Study Abroad Team.  Both teams support the University’s global network of partners to promote the development of strong and successful relationships for the long-term internationalisation of the University.

Working with the Academic Schools and the Quality Assurance and Enhancement Office (QAE), as well as other key professional support departments, the International Partnerships Office oversees and manages relationships with partners while keeping central records of partnerships and related activity.

The office provides an integrated support service to GCU staff to facilitate and realise new partnership opportunities while working directly with the University’s established partners in terms of ongoing communications and operational matters.

*   Receive new international partnership enquiries and proposal, including requests for meetings and visits to campus
*   Support and advise Academic Schools in the development of new partnerships, providing guidance material and training for staff
*   Facilitate and support operational planning with GCU schools and overseas partners
*   Manage partnership register in conjunction with QAE office
*   Manage and advise on partner communications and relationship development

## Exchange and study abroad services

*   Manage and report on Erasmus+ contract
*   Manage subject-specific and university-wide exchange and study-abroad agreements
*   Support the development of new exchange agreements
*   Support incoming and outgoing students

![Students on campus at Glasgow Caledonian University](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0022/9670/varieties/large.jpg)

## Interested in study abroad?

We've got lots of opportunities for GCU students and international students looking for a exchange and study abroad opportunities.

[Find out more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/essentials/exchange-study-abroad)

text:
Inclusive societies | Glasgow Caledonian University
We are addressing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via three societal challenges of Inclusive Societies, Healthy Lives and Sustainable Environments. Several Research Centres have been established as part of the drive to promote multi-disciplinary research across Schools, challenges and themes.
One of our research strengths is in the exploration of inclusive societies and we aim to enrich cities and communities through our research themes of social innovation and public policy; social justice, equalities and communities.
These themes are explored across the Yunus Centre for Social Business and Health and WiSE Centre for Economic Justice based within the Glasgow School for Society and Business as well as the Centre for Climate Justice based within the School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment.
At GCU we are proud to be ranked fourth in the world and first in the UK for promoting gender equality and in the top 5% globally for social impact in the 2022 Times Higher Education (THE) University Impact Rankings. We are also ranked the top modern university in Scotland for research power.
The UK Research Excellence Framework (REF2021) has classified a huge 91% of the University’s health research as world leading or internationally excellent. The REF findings defined more than 80% of the University's health research as outstanding for its impact, a result surpassed by only one other University in the UK.
Our case studies offer an insight into how we are making breakthroughs on some of today's challenges to promote inclusive societies through policy changes and social innovation.
Water for ALL
A project, funded by the Scottish Government set up to improve access to water among the poorest and most vulnerable groups in Malawi and Zambia.
Learn more arrow_forward 
Austerity’s impact on Scotland
Professor John McKendrick describes research that aims to inform the work of practitioners and campaigners who seek to tackle poverty in Scotland and the UK.
Learn more arrow_forward 
WiSE Centre for Economic Justice
The WiSE Centre is a key partner in the work that we do in government to unpick the many, many layers of economic inequality.
Learn more 
Postgraduate research study
Be part of our world-class research. Enjoy supervision and support from the award-winning Graduate School and earn Master's, PhDs, or Professional Doctorates.
Learn more 
Yunus Centre for Social Business and Health
We conduct world-leading research to improve lives and communities through a better understanding of community-based and health-focused initiatives.
Learn more
markdown:
# Inclusive societies | Glasgow Caledonian University

We are addressing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via three societal challenges of Inclusive Societies, [Healthy Lives](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/healthylives) and [Sustainable Environments](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/sustainableenvironments). Several Research Centres have been established as part of the drive to promote multi-disciplinary research across [Schools](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/gsbs/research), challenges and themes.

One of our research strengths is in the exploration of inclusive societies and we aim to enrich cities and communities through our research themes of social innovation and public policy; social justice, equalities and communities.

These themes are explored across the [Yunus Centre for Social Business and Health](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/researchcentres/yunuscentre) and [WiSE Centre for Economic Justice](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/researchcentres/wise) based within the Glasgow School for Society and Business as well as the [Centre for Climate Justice](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/researchcentres/climatejustice) based within the School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment.

At GCU we are proud to be ranked fourth in the world and first in the UK for promoting gender equality and in the top 5% globally for social impact in the [2022 Times Higher Education (THE) University Impact Rankings](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/universitynews/university-a-global-leader-in-gender-equality "University a global leader in gender equality"). We are also ranked the top modern university in Scotland for research power.

The UK Research Excellence Framework (REF2021) has classified a huge 91% of the University’s health research as world leading or internationally excellent. The REF findings defined more than 80% of the University's health research as outstanding for its impact, a result surpassed by only one other University in the UK.

Our case studies offer an insight into how we are making breakthroughs on some of today's challenges to promote inclusive societies through policy changes and social innovation.

Water for ALL

A project, funded by the Scottish Government set up to improve access to water among the poorest and most vulnerable groups in Malawi and Zambia.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/casestudies/waterforall)

Austerity’s impact on Scotland

Professor John McKendrick describes research that aims to inform the work of practitioners and campaigners who seek to tackle poverty in Scotland and the UK.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/casestudies/austeritysimpactonscotland)

WiSE Centre for Economic Justice

The WiSE Centre is a key partner in the work that we do in government to unpick the many, many layers of economic inequality.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/researchcentres/wise)

Postgraduate research study

Be part of our world-class research. Enjoy supervision and support from the award-winning Graduate School and earn Master's, PhDs, or Professional Doctorates.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/postgraduateresearchstudy)

Yunus Centre for Social Business and Health

We conduct world-leading research to improve lives and communities through a better understanding of community-based and health-focused initiatives.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/researchcentres/yunuscentre)

text:
GCU Outreach | Glasgow Caledonian University
GCU Outreach consists of five teams – School Connect, College Connect, the Caledonian Club, Routes for All and the Advanced Higher Hub - which cover the areas of outreach, widening participation, articulation, and transition support within partner schools, colleges, and communities, both in Glasgow and within GCU itself.
Although the department has a number of permanent staff, its work also relies upon a pool of employed student mentors who are recruited from GCU and work across the various teams in the department.
Caledonian Club
The Caledonian Club is Glasgow Caledonian University’s multi-award winning widening participation and community engagement initiative, working across our local communities in Glasgow, London and New York.
Learn more 
Advanced Higher Hub
GCU's on-campus centre to deliver Advanced Higher programmes to pupils from targeted Glasgow secondary schools as part of the University’s commitment to widening access to Higher Education.
Learn more 
Routes for All
The Routes for All programme has been developed to inform and guide school pupils in S5 and S6 to study Higher National Courses at college.
Learn more 
School Connect
The School Connect programme aims to provide focused interventions and support to ensure that secondary school pupils applying to GCU have the resources to gain the maximum benefit from their university studies.
Learn more 
College Connect
Whether you have been offered a place at GCU or have yet to apply, the College Connect Team provides a dedicated service at GCU to guide you through the process.
Learn more
markdown:
# GCU Outreach | Glasgow Caledonian University

GCU Outreach consists of five teams – [School Connect](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/caledonianclub), [College Connect](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/collegestudents/collegeconnect), the [Caledonian Club](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/caledonianclub), [Routes for All](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/routesforall) and [the Advanced Higher Hub](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/advancedhigherhub) -  which cover the areas of outreach, widening participation, articulation, and transition support within partner schools, colleges, and communities, both in Glasgow and within GCU itself.

Although the department has a number of permanent staff, its work also relies upon a pool of employed student mentors who are recruited from GCU and work across the various teams in the department.

Caledonian Club

The Caledonian Club is Glasgow Caledonian University’s multi-award winning widening participation and community engagement initiative, working across our local communities in Glasgow, London and New York.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/caledonianclub)

Advanced Higher Hub

GCU's on-campus centre to deliver Advanced Higher programmes to pupils from targeted Glasgow secondary schools as part of the University’s commitment to widening access to Higher Education.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/advancedhigherhub)

Routes for All

The Routes for All programme has been developed to inform and guide school pupils in S5 and S6 to study Higher National Courses at college.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/routesforall)

School Connect

The School Connect programme aims to provide focused interventions and support to ensure that secondary school pupils applying to GCU have the resources to gain the maximum benefit from their university studies.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/outreach/schoolconnect)

College Connect

Whether you have been offered a place at GCU or have yet to apply, the College Connect Team provides a dedicated service at GCU to guide you through the process.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/collegestudents/collegeconnect)

text:
Travel directions | Glasgow Caledonian University
Location map and directions
Walking
Glasgow's an easy city to walk around. Use WalkIt.com to plan your route and find out how long it will take you, how many steps you'll use and even how many calories you'll burn (865 steps and 42 calories between Glasgow Queen Street Station and the University).
Bicycle
The university has lots of secure cycle racks where you can park your bike. Find out more about cycling in Glasgow.
Bus
The University is directly opposite Glasgow's main bus terminal Buchanan Bus Station.
Underground
The university is a short walk from Cowcaddens underground station - great for seeing some more of the city while you are here.
Rail
Situated in the city centre, our Glasgow campus is a short walk from Glasgow Queen Street Station and about 20 minutes walk from Glasgow Central Station. Visit National Rail Enquiries Service for train times.
Car
The university is easily accessible from Junction 16 (Westbound) or Junctions 15 & 17 (Eastbound) of the M8 motorway.
Although no parking is available on campus, the nearest car parks to the university are a short walk away:
Concert Square multistorey on Cowcaddens road
Cambridge street multistorey
Since June, 1 all vehicles entering the city centre zone area must meet the less-polluting emission standards or face a penalty charge. Some exemptions apply.
Find out whether your car qualifies by visiting Transport Scotland's vehicle registration checker.
Interested in car sharing to save money and help save the environment? Find out more at SPT Journeyshare, Liftshare and Carpool World.
Airport
Glasgow Airport is situated approximately 10 miles to the west of the City Centre - approximately 30 minutes by taxi. There is also a direct bus link to Buchanan Bus Station, which is 200 yards from the University.
markdown:
# Travel directions | Glasgow Caledonian University

### Location map and directions

### Walking

Glasgow's an easy city to walk around. Use [WalkIt.com](https://walkit.com/travel/) to plan your route and find out how long it will take you, how many steps you'll use and even how many calories you'll burn (865 steps and 42 calories between [Glasgow Queen Street Station](http://www.nationalrail.co.uk/stations/GLQ.html) and the University).

### Bicycle

The university has lots of secure cycle racks where you can park your bike. Find out more about [cycling in Glasgow](http://www.glasgow.gov.uk/en/Residents/GettingAround/Cycling/).

### Bus

The University is directly opposite Glasgow's main bus terminal [Buchanan Bus Station](https://www.spt.co.uk/travel-with-spt/bus/bus-stations-travel-information/bus-stations/buchanan-bus-station-glasgow/).

### Underground

The university is a short walk from [Cowcaddens underground station](http://www.spt.co.uk/subway/ "Glasgow underground") - great for seeing some more of the city while you are here.

### Rail

Situated in the city centre, our Glasgow campus is a short walk from [Glasgow Queen Street Station](http://www.nationalrail.co.uk/stations/GLQ.html) and about 20 minutes walk from [Glasgow Central Station](https://www.scotrail.co.uk/plan-your-journey/stations-and-facilities/glc). Visit [National Rail Enquiries Service](http://www.nationalrail.co.uk/) for train times.

### Car

The university is easily accessible from Junction 16 (Westbound) or Junctions 15 & 17 (Eastbound) of the M8 motorway.

Although no parking is available on campus, the nearest car parks to the university are a short walk away:

*   [Concert Square multistorey](https://glasgow.gov.uk/index.aspx?articleid=27314) on Cowcaddens road
*   [Cambridge street multistorey](https://glasgow.gov.uk/index.aspx?articleid=27160)

Since June, 1 all vehicles entering the city centre zone area must meet the less-polluting emission standards or face a penalty charge. [Some exemptions](https://www.lowemissionzones.scot/blue-badge-exemption) apply.

Find out whether your car qualifies by visiting [Transport Scotland's vehicle registration checker](https://www.lowemissionzones.scot/vehicle-registration-checker).

Interested in car sharing to save money and help save the environment? Find out more at [SPT Journeyshare](https://spt.liftshare.com/), [Liftshare](https://www.liftshare.com/uk/) and [Carpool World](http://www.carpoolworld.com/carpool_.html?home_city=Glasgow&home_state_prov=&home_postal_zip=G76%208HZ&country=GBR,UK&to=Edinburgh&state=&work_postal_zip=EH11%201DQ&country=GBR,UK&polat=55.7888712&polon=-4.2401642&plat=55.9405402&plon=-3.2194771).

### Airport

[Glasgow Airport](http://www.glasgowairport.com/) is situated approximately 10 miles to the west of the City Centre - approximately 30 minutes by taxi. There is also a direct bus link to [Buchanan Bus Station](https://www.spt.co.uk/travel-with-spt/bus/bus-stations-travel-information/bus-stations/buchanan-bus-station-glasgow/), which is 200 yards from the University.

International outlook | Glasgow Caledonian University
As an internationalised university we are concerned with the development of a multicultural community of students and staff, preparing its students for global political and social environments, and the development of international alliances in research, education and business.
Our commitment to internationalisation
Internationalisation is one of the major forces shaping higher education. We have made significant progress through the recruitment of a growing international community of students, the appointment of international staff, the development of a range of international alliances based on research and scholarships, student exchanges, articulation agreements with overseas institutions and our successful validation partnership with the National University of Science and Technology in Oman.
Our Internationalisation Strategy is interlinked with the University's Learning and Teaching and Research and Knowledge Transfer strategies.
Welcoming students
At both our Glasgow and London campuses, we provide our international students with superb facilities, teaching excellence and high-quality vocational education. These are just a few of the reasons that GCU is the top choice for students from more than 130 countries. We have a dedicated Visa Immigration Support & Advice (VISA) team to assist current and prospective international GCU students and their dependents.
We aim to offer all of our students an opportunity for cultural exchange - whether that's our international students coming to UK or our local students going abroad via summer schools, exchanges and study abroad.
Globally networked: International strategic partnerships
Glasgow Caledonian’s excellent international reputation stems not only from our award-winning support for international students at the University, but also our work with our many partners around the world.
The development of long-term partnerships with overseas institutions is a fundamental part of Glasgow Caledonian University’s Internationalisation Strategy. From Articulation and pathway partnerships, student and staff mobility, through to overseas campus partnerships the University is dedicated to increasing its global network.
The International Partnerships Office coordinates and facilitates the University's work with international partners.
International research collaboration
Glasgow Caledonian University's in-house research innovation team works on European and Internationally funded collaborative projects.
markdown:
# International outlook | Glasgow Caledonian University

As an internationalised university we are concerned with the development of a multicultural community of students and staff, preparing its students for global political and social environments, and the development of international alliances in research, education and business.

## Our commitment to internationalisation

Internationalisation is one of the major forces shaping higher education. We have made significant progress through the recruitment of a growing international community of students, the appointment of international staff, the development of a range of international alliances based on research and scholarships, student exchanges, articulation agreements with overseas institutions and our successful validation partnership with the [National University of Science and Technology](https://www.nu.edu.om/) in Oman.

Our Internationalisation Strategy is interlinked with the University's Learning and Teaching and Research and Knowledge Transfer strategies.

## Welcoming students

At both our Glasgow and London campuses, we provide our international students with superb facilities, teaching excellence and high-quality vocational education. These are just a few of the reasons that GCU is the top choice for students from more than 130 countries. We have a dedicated [Visa Immigration Support & Advice (VISA) team](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/support/international) to assist current and prospective international GCU students and their dependents.

We aim to offer all of our students an opportunity for cultural exchange - whether that's our international students coming to UK or our local students going abroad via [summer schools](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/internationalstudy/summerschool), [exchanges and study abroad](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/essentials/exchange-study-abroad).

## Globally networked: International strategic partnerships

Glasgow Caledonian’s excellent international reputation stems not only from our award-winning support for international students at the University, but also our work with our many partners around the world.

The development of long-term partnerships with overseas institutions is a fundamental part of Glasgow Caledonian University’s Internationalisation Strategy. From Articulation and pathway partnerships, student and staff mobility, through to overseas campus partnerships the University is dedicated to increasing its global network.

The [International Partnerships Office](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/international/internationalpartnerships) coordinates and facilitates the University's work with international partners.

## International research collaboration

Glasgow Caledonian University's in-house [research innovation team](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/innovation "Home%20%BB%20GCU%20%BB%20Research%20%BB%20Research%20Innovation%20Office") works on European and Internationally funded collaborative projects.

# GCU London | London, UK

## Find your course

### Applications are open for January 2025

We have lots of options to help you discover the right path for your future. Apply today for postgraduate study and join the UK’s Modern University of the year (Daily Mail University Guide 2025)

## British School of Fashion

We're home to the industry-leading British School of Fashion and deliver fast-paced, business-focused courses, led by industry insiders and researchers at the forefront of sustainability and innovation. We'll equip you with the skills and experience you need for a career in the luxury, lifestyle, or fashion sectors. We're a trailblazer, offering the UK’s first MBA in Luxury Brand Management, as well as MSc courses in Sustainable Fashion Business, Luxury Marketing, and Fashion and Lifestyle Marketing.

[Find out more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/london/about-gcu-london/british-school-of-fashion)

## Research

As the University for the Common Good, our projects work locally and internationally to support the UN's Sustainable Development Goals and we need research students like you who are ready to help us go further.

Find a room
The letter at the beginning of the room number tells you which building the room is in (the letters in brackets in the list above). The first number tells you what floor of the building it is on and the last digits tell you the room number. So M525 would be: M = George Moore Building, 5 = fifth floor, 25 = room 25.
Examples:
Room M525 is George Moore Building 5th Floor
Room A005 is Govan Mbeki Health Building Ground floor
Room M201 is George Moore Building 2nd Floor
markdown:
# Campus map | Glasgow Caledonian University

![Small Map](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0015/65040/Small_Campus_wide_445_wide.jpg)

### Key

![Disabled sign](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0035/69983/disabled_25.gif)Access (Lifts, ramps and automatic doors)

![Food sign](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0036/69984/food_25.gif)Food and drink

### Download Campus Map

[Download the map (pdf)](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0025/74581/Campus_Map_2022.pdf)

### University Buildings (letters in brackets are the building room number prefix)

1.  Annie Lennox Building (W)
2.  The Sir Alex Ferguson Library
3.  George Moore Building (M) Restaurant, Study Club and Campus Life desk
4.  Govan Mbeki Building (A)
5.  Students’ Association
6.  Arc Health and Wellbeing Facility
7.  Centre for Executive Education (CEE) Registration and student cards here
8.  William Harley Building (H)
9.  Britannia Building (B)
10.  Charles Oakley Laboratories (C)
11.  Teaching Block (T)
12.  Milton Street Building (MS)
13.  Nursery
14.  Caledonian Court (Student Accommodation)

### Find a room

The letter at the beginning of the room number tells you which building the room is in (the letters in brackets in the list above). The first number tells you what floor of the building it is on and the last digits tell you the room number. So M525 would be: M = George Moore Building, 5 = fifth floor, 25 = room 25.

Examples:

*   Room M525 is George Moore Building 5th Floor
*   Room A005 is Govan Mbeki Health Building Ground floor
*   Room M201 is George Moore Building 2nd Floor

As the University for the Common Good, our research focuses on finding solutions to three of society’s biggest challenges; living Healthy lives, building Inclusive societies and creating Sustainable environments. Our projects work locally and internationally to support the UN's Sustainable Development Goals and we need research students like you who are ready to help us go further.
Choose Glasgow Caledonian University and be part of world-class research, which focuses on excellence and quality. You’ll have access to our innovative Research Centres. You’ll be supported by a community of academic staff and over 500 research students from more than 50 countries. At GCU, ideas, expertise and experiences can be shared, challenged and developed.

markdown:
# Postgraduate research study | Glasgow Caledonian University

As the University for the Common Good, our research focuses on finding solutions to three of society’s biggest challenges; living [Healthy lives](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/healthylives), building [Inclusive societies](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/inclusivesocieties) and creating [Sustainable environments](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/sustainableenvironments). Our projects work locally and internationally to support the UN's [Sustainable Development Goals](https://sdgs.un.org/goals) and we need research students like you who are ready to help us go further.

Choose Glasgow Caledonian University and be part of world-class research, which focuses on excellence and quality. You’ll have access to our innovative Research Centres. With well established, international reputations, their pioneering work is influencing and informing policy decisions and technological advancements.

You’ll be supported by a community of academic staff and over 500 research students from more than 50 countries. At GCU, ideas, expertise and experiences can be shared, challenged and developed.

You can choose to progress to the next level of research that can lead to further academia or more demanding leadership roles.

PhD opportunities

You can find a PhD project using our search facility and filter your search to view funded, competition funded and self-funded opportunities.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/postgraduateresearchstudy/phdopportunities)

Application process

You can submit your PhD application using our online application portal and select from a list of strategic research subjects and intakes.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/postgraduateresearchstudy/applicationprocess)

Fees and funding

Learn more about postgraduate research fees and explore options for funding support.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/postgraduateresearchstudy/feesandfunding)

Research online

Glasgow Caledonian University is addressing the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) via three societal challenges of Inclusive societies; Healthy lives and Sus

[Learn more](https://researchonline.gcu.ac.uk/)

Our welcoming university community of 1,500 staff and nearly 22,000 students from more than 130 countries enjoy state-of-the-art facilities across each of our campuses in Glasgow, London and our postgraduate college based in New York, with transnational partnerships in China, South Africa, Oman and Mauritius.
Our academic schools offer a wide range of high quality programmes, professional training courses, research opportunities and consultancy services.
Highlights include:
More building and surveying graduates than anywhere else in the UK
The UK’s only honours degree in Risk Management
Innovative computer game development and multimedia courses
Wide range of industry-accredited courses
Major provider of health, social care and life sciences graduates for the NHS
School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment
GCU's School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of three academic schools with strong industry links supported by innovation in our teaching
Learn more 
Glasgow School for Business and Society
The Glasgow School for Business and Society integrates the areas of business, law and social sciences to ensure that they are well placed to meet the needs of business and society.
Learn more 
School of Health and Life Sciences
The School of Health and Life Sciences is committed to the pursuit of excellence in teaching, research and knowledge transfer across the disciplines of health, nursing and social care, biological and biomedical sciences, psychology and vision sciences.
Learn more 
GCU London
Situated in the heart of the city, our London campus, offers students a great location, diverse student community and globally recognised courses.
Learn more 
How to apply
You can apply to GCU online.
Apply now 
Open Days and campus tours
Find out more about our undergraduate courses and student life at GCU
Register today

# Academic schools | Glasgow Caledonian University

Our welcoming university community of 1,500 staff and nearly 22,000 students from more than 130 countries enjoy state-of-the-art facilities across each of our campuses in Glasgow, London and our postgraduate college based in New York, with transnational partnerships in China, South Africa, Oman and Mauritius.

Our academic schools offer a wide range of high quality programmes, professional training courses, research opportunities and consultancy services.

Highlights include:

*   More building and surveying graduates than anywhere else in the UK
*   The UK’s only honours degree in Risk Management
*   Innovative computer game development and multimedia courses
*   Wide range of industry-accredited courses
*   Major provider of health, social care and life sciences graduates for the NHS

School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment

GCU's School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment is one of three academic schools with strong industry links supported by innovation in our teaching

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/cebe)

Glasgow School for Business and Society

The Glasgow School for Business and Society integrates the areas of business, law and social sciences to ensure that they are well placed to meet the needs of business and society.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/gsbs)

School of Health and Life Sciences

The School of Health and Life Sciences is committed to the pursuit of excellence in teaching, research and knowledge transfer across the disciplines of health, nursing and social care, biological and biomedical sciences, psychology and vision sciences.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/aboutgcu/academicschools/hls)

GCU London

Situated in the heart of the city, our London campus, offers students a great location, diverse student community and globally recognised courses.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/london)

![](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0023/9392/varieties/large.jpg)

## How to apply

You can apply to GCU online.

[Apply now](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/undergraduate/howtoapply)

## Open Days and campus tours

Find out more about our undergraduate courses and student life at GCU

[Register today](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/opendays)

Research Innovation Office | Glasgow Caledonian University
The Research and Innovation Office (RIO) team supports the University’s research and innovation environment through five support units:
Helping to embed a research culture within the University and overseeing the University’s REF Submission.
Driving innovation through KTPs and innovation vouchers.
Specialising in international collaboration projects.
Finding solutions for Business in our consultancy and contract research
Supporting social innovation through knowledge exchange.
Our aim is to attain research excellence by optimising the research output of academic staff while developing a dynamic culture of innovation amongst staff across the University.
Our team will support research funding applications, management of contractual agreements, project costing and engagement with business partners including innovation support, such as knowledge transfer partnerships (KTPs). 
We also manage internationally funded projects and help to embed social innovation within the University and beyond through our unique portfolio of projects, including EU funding.
Glasgow Caledonian University's RIO team focuses on five key, interrelated areas or units of activity:
markdown:
# Research Innovation Office | Glasgow Caledonian University

The Research and Innovation Office (RIO) team supports the University’s research and innovation environment through five support units:

*   Helping to embed a research culture within the University and overseeing the University’s REF Submission.
*   Driving innovation through KTPs and innovation vouchers.
*   Specialising in international collaboration projects.
*   Finding solutions for Business in our consultancy and contract research
*   Supporting social innovation through knowledge exchange.

Our aim is to attain research excellence by optimising the research output of academic staff while developing a dynamic culture of innovation amongst staff across the University.

Our team will support research funding applications, management of contractual agreements, project costing and engagement with business partners including innovation support, such as knowledge transfer partnerships (KTPs).

We also manage internationally funded projects and help to embed social innovation within the University and beyond through our unique portfolio of projects, including EU funding.

Glasgow Caledonian University's RIO team focuses on five key, interrelated areas or units of activity:

text:
Complaints | Glasgow Caledonian University
Glasgow Caledonian University values complaints from anyone who interacts with our services and we appreciate feedback from individuals on their interactions with, and observations of the University. Comments on University activities and decisions are welcome and where clarification or requests for decisions to be explained more fully are sought, these are responded to swiftly at source.
In recognition of that, on occasion, there will be legitimate complaints that individuals wish to raise, the University is committed to maintaining an effective Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP). Glasgow Caledonian also recognises that lessons can be learned from complaints, enabling us to improve the quality and effectiveness of our services.
Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP)
The CHP is designed to ensure that complaints are properly investigated and are given careful and fair consideration. The CHP can be used by anyone who interacts with the University, including:
Current students
Applicants
Recent graduates of the University
Members of the public.
If you wish to raise a concern about the conduct of a GCU student, this sits outwith the CHP and you should submit your concerns to sdc@gcu.ac.uk Similarly, if you have concerns about the Students' Association please contact the Students' Association directly. Members of GCU staff who wish to raise a concern about matters related to their employment should do this via the University's Staff Conflict and Complaints Policy
If you wish to make a complaint relating to racism or gender-based and sexual violence or misconduct by a student or member of staff, you can do that via complaints@gcu.ac.uk or by telephoning 0141 331 8226. Your complaint will be treated sensitively and you will be informed of the support that is available to you. If you have experienced gender-based and sexual violence or misconduct, you may wish to contact a GCU First Responder directly. First Responders have received training in listening and responding to disclosures of gender-based violence. They can provide information and signpost you to sources of support both internally and externally. This resource is available to both staff and students.
You can also make a report about any form of inappropriate or offensive behaviour via Report and Support. There are two types of reports you can make through Report and Support. You can choose to tell us either anonymously, or by including your name and contact details. Please note, if reports are submitted anonymously the University is limited in the action it can take, the support we can provide, and the reporter will not receive any information relating to any potential action taken.
Also, Report and Support is not designed to receive urgent reports. If you need immediate support or feel in crisis, we have listed several support and emergency services contact details on the GCU Wellbeing webpages you may find helpful. If you submit a report in Report and Support and supply your details you will be contacted within two working days of submission of a report. The Report and Support tool is monitored 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays and periods of University closure.
Making a complaint
The Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP) involves up to two stages and adheres, as far as possible, to specified timescales. Anyone wishing to raise a complaint about a matter which is the responsibility of the University must do so via the procedure.
Glasgow Caledonian University Complaints Procedure - CHP Part 5 A guide for complainants
Stage 1: Frontline resolution
If you are considering making a complaint to the University, you should first:
Try to sort out the problem with those who are directly involved. General complaints are resolved more easily and effectively at an early stage and by those who have a direct influence on the situation. We call this ‘Frontline Resolution’.
Have a look at the Guidance and Information section below.
If you are a student, you may wish to contact a Student Adviser at the Glasgow Caledonian University Students’ Association (GCUSA) for advice and support. GCUSA Student Advisers have a great deal of relevant experience and knowledge of University procedures and can support students throughout the complaints process.
Stage 2: Complaint investigation
If you cannot resolve your issue via Frontline Resolution or you feel the matter is significant enough to merit a formal investigation, contact a member of staff in the Department of Governance who will talk you through the Complaints Handling Procedure and help you decide how to proceed.
Staff in the department can be contacted at complaints@gcu.ac.uk or via telephone on +44 (0)141 331 8226.
It may help you in submitting a request for a Stage 2 Complaint Investigation if you complete this form - Complaint Form April 2021
Guidance and information on the Complaints Handling Procedure
CHP Part 1 Introduction and Overview
CHP Part 2 When to use this procedure - advice for staff
CHP Part 3 A guide for staff
CHP Part 4 Governance
Complaints Flowchart
Unacceptable Actions Policy
The Unacceptable Actions Policy sets out expected standards of behaviours for anyone using the Complaints Handling Procedure and specifies how we will manage cases where behaviour is problematic.
Scottish Public Services Ombudsman
If a complainant has exhausted all of the stages of the University Complaints Handling Procedure and they are dissatisfied with the way in which their complaint has been handled by the University then they have the right to take their case to the Scottish Public Services Ombudsman (SPSO). The SPSO will consider the case and make a decision on whether or not to investigate.
The SPSO can only consider complaints when they have been through all stages of the University’s Complaints Handling Procedure. The SPSO cannot normally look at complaints:
Where you have not gone all the way through the University's Complaints Handling Procedure
More than 12 months after you become aware of the matter you want to complain about
That have been or are being considered in court.
Visit the SPSO website for information on how to complain to the SPSO and how the SPSO handles complaints.
Complaints Overview
Complaints Overview 2013/14
‌Complaints Overview 2014/15
‌Complaints Overview 2015-16
Complaints Overview 2016/17
Complaints Overview 2017/18
Complaints Overview 2018/19
Complaints Overview 2019/20
Complaints Overviews 2020/21
Complaints Overviews 2021/22
Complaints Overviews 2022/23
markdown:
# Complaints | Glasgow Caledonian University

Glasgow Caledonian University values complaints from anyone who interacts with our services and we appreciate feedback from individuals on their interactions with, and observations of the University. Comments on University activities and decisions are welcome and where clarification or requests for decisions to be explained more fully are sought, these are responded to swiftly at source.

In recognition of that, on occasion, there will be legitimate complaints that individuals wish to raise, the University is committed to maintaining an effective Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP). Glasgow Caledonian also recognises that lessons can be learned from complaints, enabling us to improve the quality and effectiveness of our services.

## Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP)

The CHP is designed to ensure that complaints are properly investigated and are given careful and fair consideration. The CHP can be used by anyone who interacts with the University, including:

*   Current students
*   Applicants
*   Recent graduates of the University
*   Members of the public.

If you wish to raise a concern about the conduct of a GCU student, this sits outwith the CHP and you should submit your concerns to [sdc@gcu.ac.uk](mailto:sdc@gcu.ac.uk) Similarly, if you have concerns about the Students' Association please [contact the Students' Association directly](https://www.gcustudents.co.uk/resources/complaints-procedure-f548). Members of GCU staff who wish to raise a concern about matters related to their employment should do this via the University's [Staff Conflict and Complaints Policy](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/38706/staff20conflict20and20complaints20resolution20policy20.pdf)

If you wish to make a complaint relating to racism or gender-based and sexual violence or misconduct by a student or member of staff, you can do that via [complaints@gcu.ac.uk](mailto:complaints@gcu.ac.uk) or by telephoning 0141 331 8226. Your complaint will be treated sensitively and you will be informed of the support that is available to you. If you have experienced gender-based and sexual violence or misconduct, you may wish to contact a GCU First Responder directly. First Responders have received training in listening and responding to disclosures of gender-based violence. They can provide information and signpost you to sources of support both internally and externally. This resource is available to both staff and students.

You can also make a report about any form of inappropriate or offensive behaviour via [Report and Support](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/support/reportandsupport).  There are two types of reports you can make through Report and Support. You can choose to tell us either anonymously, or by including your name and contact details. Please note, if reports are submitted anonymously the University is limited in the action it can take, the support we can provide, and the reporter will not receive any information relating to any potential action taken.

Also, Report and Support is not designed to receive urgent reports. If you need immediate support or feel in crisis, we have listed several support and emergency services contact details on the [GCU Wellbeing webpages](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/currentstudents/support/wellbeing) you may find helpful.  If you submit a report in Report and Support and supply your details you will be contacted within two working days of submission of a report. The Report and Support tool is monitored 9am to 5pm Monday to Friday, excluding public holidays and periods of University closure.

### Making a complaint

The Complaints Handling Procedure (CHP) involves up to two stages and adheres, as far as possible, to specified timescales.  Anyone wishing to raise a complaint about a matter which is the responsibility of the University must do so via the procedure.

Glasgow Caledonian University Complaints Procedure - [CHP Part 5 A guide for complainants](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0023/36509/chp20part20520a20guide20for20complainants.pdf)

#### Stage 1: Frontline resolution

If you are considering making a complaint to the University, you should first:

*   Try to sort out the problem with those who are directly involved. General complaints are resolved more easily and effectively at an early stage and by those who have a direct influence on the situation. We call this ‘Frontline Resolution’.
*   Have a look at the Guidance and Information section below.
*   If you are a student, you may wish to contact a Student Adviser at the [Glasgow Caledonian University Students’ Association (GCUSA)](https://www.gcustudents.co.uk/) for advice and support. GCUSA Student Advisers have a great deal of relevant experience and knowledge of University procedures and can support students throughout the complaints process.

#### Stage 2: Complaint investigation

If you cannot resolve your issue via Frontline Resolution or you feel the matter is significant enough to merit a formal investigation, contact a member of staff in the Department of Governance who will talk you through the Complaints Handling Procedure and help you decide how to proceed.

Staff in the department can be contacted at [complaints@gcu.ac.uk](mailto:complaints@gcu.ac.uk) or via telephone on +44 (0)141 331 8226.

It may help you in submitting a request for a Stage 2 Complaint Investigation if you complete this form - [Complaint Form April 2021](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/word_doc/0015/34035/complaint20form20april202021.docx)

### Guidance and information on the Complaints Handling Procedure

*   [CHP Part 1 Introduction and Overview](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0025/36538/chp20part20120introduction20and20overview.pdf)
*   [CHP Part 2 When to use this procedure - advice for staff](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0024/38409/chp20part20220when20to20use20this20procedure20advice20for20staff.pdf)
*   [CHP Part 3 A guide for staff](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0031/35779/chp20part20320a20guide20for20staff.pdf)
*   [CHP Part 4 Governance](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0017/33155/chp20part20420governance.pdf)
*   [Complaints Flowchart](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0026/36593/gcu_chp_flowchart.pdf)

### Unacceptable Actions Policy

The [Unacceptable Actions Policy](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0018/34182/unacceptable20actions20policy.pdf) sets out expected standards of behaviours for anyone using the Complaints Handling Procedure and specifies how we will manage cases where behaviour is problematic.

### Scottish Public Services Ombudsman

If a complainant has exhausted all of the stages of the University Complaints Handling Procedure and they are dissatisfied with the way in which their complaint has been handled by the University then they have the right to take their case to the Scottish Public Services Ombudsman (SPSO). The SPSO will consider the case and make a decision on whether or not to investigate.

The SPSO can only consider complaints when they have been through all stages of the University’s Complaints Handling Procedure. The SPSO cannot normally look at complaints:

*   Where you have not gone all the way through the University's Complaints Handling Procedure
*   More than 12 months after you become aware of the matter you want to complain about
*   That have been or are being considered in court.

Visit the [SPSO website](http://www.spso.org.uk/ "Scottish Public Services Ombudsman") for information on how to complain to the SPSO and how the SPSO handles complaints.

### Complaints Overview

*   [Complaints Overview 2013/14](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0028/30799/complaints-overview-13-14.pdf)
*   ‌[Complaints Overview 2014/15](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0020/35534/complaints20overview202014-15.pdf)
*   ‌[Complaints Overview 2015-16](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/pdf_file/0019/35506/complaints20overview202015.16.pdf)
*   [Complaints Overview 2016/17](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/word_doc/0018/34119/complaints20overview202016.17.docx)
*   [Complaints Overview 2017/18](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/word_doc/0021/37524/complaints20information20for20website2017.18.docx)
*   [Complaints Overview 2018/19](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/word_doc/0025/35368/complaints20overview202018-19.docx)
*   [Complaints Overview 2019/20](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/word_doc/0024/35781/complaints202019-2020website20overview.docx)

markdown:
# Graduate School | Glasgow Caledonian University

Join the Graduate School and become part of a collaborative research environment and community. Partnership and research culture are at the heart of our researcher development programme. We provide expertise and advice to all, wherever you are on your research journey so please [get in touch.](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/graduateschool/contacts)

Our Graduate School is at the heart of GCU's research community. We work in close partnership with the university's academic schools, support departments and external collaborators to enhance all aspects of our researchers' personal and professional career development. We provide expertise and advice to all, wherever you are on your research journey.

Our work includes:

*   Researcher Development provision for research students and staff through our extensive workshop programme
*   Tailored academic writing provision for research students and research staff
*   Enhancement of the research student experience
*   Championing a positive research culture for all researchers
*   Co-ordination of administration and monitoring of quality standards for research student progression and awards

We also run social and intellectual events throughout the academic year that bring together our research community of research students and staff. This includes dedicated spaces where researchers can socialise and share ideas.

![BA (Hons) International Business student in classroom at Glasgow Caledonian University](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0009/10341/varieties/large.jpg)

## Researcher Development

One of our core activities at the Graduate School is offering development opportunities for you to progress through your research studies.

[Learn more](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/graduateschool/researcherdevelopment)

Academic Writing Centre

GCU offers a range of workshops tailored to the specific demands of academic writing at each stage of the doctoral journey or research process

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/graduateschool/researcherdevelopment/academicwritingcentre)

The Research Student Handbook

This handbook will be essential as part of your Induction but should also be referred to throughout your Research Student Journey.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/graduateschool/theresearchstudenthandbook)

Workshops

We offer a range of training designed to enhance your development as a research student. Check out our available workshops.

[Learn more arrow\_forward](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/graduateschool/researcherdevelopment/workshops)

Glasgow Caledonian is an exciting and vibrant city centre University with a strong research community of academic staff and research students. There are currently over 450 research students at GCU studying towards a PhD, Professional Doctorate or Doctorate of Business Administration  - with students from over 50 countries worldwide, this creates a forum for a rich interchange of ideas, expertise and experiences.

### Postgraduate research study at GCU

![PG Students studeying](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/__data/assets/image/0024/4938/varieties/medium.jpg)

#### How to apply

Before you begin an application, you are invited and encouraged to contact the research supervisor(s). You can view our PhD opportunities online.

#### Academic Schools

PhD students join one of the three Academic Schools: Glasgow School for Business and Society; School of Computing, Engineering and Built Environment; School of Health and Life Sciences.

#### Research study guidelines

View our regulation and guidelines.

[Learn More](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/research/postgraduateresearchstudy)

text:
Americas | Glasgow Caledonian University
Glasgow Caledonian University has become one of the largest universities in Scotland with more than 22,000 students. Our international students come from over 130 different countries throughout the world and bring with them a diversity and enthusiasm which undoubtedly enriches the Caledonian experience for everyone.
Come meet us 
Our team at GCU takes part in various events throughout the year to advice and support you throughout the application process.
Talk to the team 
You can get in touch using our contact form or contact a member of the International Recruitment team if you would like to arrange a meeting in your country.
For North America, please contact Lorna Campbell, Recruitment and Marketing Manager.
If you are currently living in the UK, we would love to show you around. Come see our campuses in Glasgow and London, with Open Days and Tours.

Open Days
Visit us to explore our campus, courses, and facilities, and to experience life at GCU firsthand during our university open days. Connect with peers, take a campus and accommodation tour, and gain insights from our staff and students about studying with us.

Discover a range of financial help available to students, including funded scholarships, bursaries, tuition fee reductions and loyalty rewards.

# Americas | Glasgow Caledonian University

Glasgow Caledonian University has become one of the largest universities in Scotland with more than 22,000 students. Our international students come from over 130 different countries throughout the world and bring with them a diversity and enthusiasm which undoubtedly enriches the Caledonian experience for everyone.

Come meet us

Our team at GCU takes part in various events throughout the year to advice and support you throughout the application process.

Talk to the team

You can get in touch using [our contact form](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/enquire)  or contact a member of the International Recruitment team if you would like to arrange a meeting in your country.

For North America, please contact [Lorna Campbell](mailto:lorna.campbell@gcu.ac.uk), Recruitment and Marketing Manager.

If you are currently living in the UK, we would love to show you around. Come see our campuses in Glasgow and London, with [Open Days and Tours.](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/study/opendaysandtours)

## More about your country

*   **[Canada](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/internationalstudy/americas/canada)**
*   **[Dominican Republic](https://www.gcu.ac.uk/internationalstudy/americas/dominicanrepublic)**
